DOC.HEAD: Two Public Officials Agree Not to Pray at High School Games
DOC.TEXT: Two public officials who defied the Supreme Court by leading a prayer before a high school football game in August have decided not to fight the case in court. Mayor Emory Folmar and Montgomery County Commission Chairman William Joseph agreed not to conduct prayers before high school football games, saying the school board has control over pregame activities at the city-owned stadium. The reponse Wednesday by Folmar and Joseph to civil libertarians who filed a lawsuit over the pre-game prayers leaves only a slim chance that the case will go to trial as scheduled Jan. 4, attorneys said. ``I think they've done the responsible thing,'' David Schoen, a Montgomery attorney who filed the suit, said Thursday. A federal judge last month dismissed the Montgomery County Board of Education from the case because it agreed not to sanction or permit prayers before school-sponsored events. Folmar and Joseph said they would honor that agreement. ``It's not a question of saying we were wrong or they were wrong or the world is wrong,'' said Folmar. ``We in effect were stopped from doing it by the school board.''
